head.p: This manuscript - Cotton MS Julius E.vii - dates to the first third of the 11th century and therefore contains one of the earliest known copies of Ælfric's Lives of Saints, along with two other texts associated with him as well asand four anonymous saints' lives (Euphrosyne, Eustace, Mary of Egypt and the Seven Sleepers). It was probably made in the Benedictine Abbey of Bury St Edmunds or at Canterbury. It contains glosses and corrections which appear to have been written in the early 11th century.

summary.p: This manuscript contains one of the earliest known copies of Ælfric's Lives of Saints, along with two other texts associated with Ælfric and four possibly anonymous saints' lives (Euphrosyne, Eustace, Mary of Egypt, and the Seven Sleepers). All of these texts were apparently intended as a single volume. The table of contents (f. 4v) includes a reference to another text, De duodicem abusivis, was intended to be included after De falsis diis, but it is not now present. Many of the glosses and corrections appear to have been written in the early 11th century.

msContents.textLang: Predominantly in Old English with a few isolated Latin words and phrases.

binding.p: Binding done in-house (British Museum or British Library). Rebound in 1914.

extent.p: One parchment codex, measuring approximately 290 x 250 mm. Fos. i + 241 (where ff. i and 1 are early modern endleaves and f. 2 is a Cottonian frontispiece).

layoutDesc.layout: Text is written in a single column per parchment leaf.

handNote.p: The manuscript is written in English vernacular miniscule and English Caroline miniscule.

decoDesc.p: Ornate red initials throughout. Some rubrication is now grey.

origin.p: Southern England (? the Benedictine abbey of Bury St Edmunds, or Canterbury): probably written by one scribe, 1st half of the 11th century (see Ker, Catalogue (1957), p. 210; Stokes, English Vernacular Miniscule (2014), p. 143).

provenance.p: The Benedictine abbey of Bury St Edmunds, 13th century:inscribed 'Liber sancti Ædmundi regis [et] martyris'(f. 3r).

Sir Robert Bruce Cotton (b. 1571, d. 1631), 1st baronet, antiquary and politician: the volume was in Cotton's possession by 1621 and is recorded in the catalogue of the Cottonian collection, Harley MS 6018, no. 179. This item was perhaps once bound with Cotton MS Tiberius B II, ff. 2–85.

Cotton’s collection was augmented by his son, Sir Thomas Cotton, 2nd baronet (b. 1594, d. 1662), and his grandson, Sir John Cotton (his name is inscribed on f. 3r). Sir John Cotton, 3rd baronet (b. 1621, d. 1702) bequeathed the entire Cotton collection of books and manuscripts to trustees ‘for Publick Use and Advantage’, 12 and 13 William III, c. 7. Formed one of the foundation collections of the British Museum in 1753.

projectDesc.p: No edition of Aelfric’s Lives of Saints (LS) has yet been published electronically beyond the digitized photographs found on the British Library website. The Aelfric Scriptorium Project (TASP) is working to provide facing transcriptions, translations, running commentaries, glossaries, and other ancillary research materials so that these texts can be better understood and properly placed within their literary, historical, theological, and cultural contexts.

normalization.p: In an effort to preserve all spelling variants in a world without standardized spelling, we have rendered all words as they appear in the MS.
